awd_titl_txt: CRII: NeTS: Exploiting System and Network Dynamics in Mobile Clouds
awd_abstract_narration:
This project focuses on exploiting various aspects of mobile system and wireless network dynamics to improve the efficiency of mobile cloud computing. Exploitation of these dynamics has substantial impacts on practical integration of mobile devices into the cloud, by alleviating the local computation burden of mobile devices and allowing adaptation to the heterogeneous system and environmental contexts. The research results are likely to inspire novel theoretical and systematic studies that open up new areas of research in highly interactive mobile computing systems. The project plans to engage female and under-represented minority students in the research activities and disseminate the research results broadly to the community.

Mobile cloud computing bridges the gap between the limited capabilities of mobile devices and the increasing complexity of mobile applications, by offloading the computational workloads from local devices to the remote cloud. However, the effectiveness of mobile cloud computing could be impaired by the dynamic nature of system and network contexts, which lead to heterogeneous mobile application behaviors and seriously reduce the appropriateness of workload offloading decisions. The goal of this research is to exploit these critical dynamics in mobile clouds that are indispensable to efficient, prompt, and reliable workload offloading. More specifically, the project addresses three closely intertwined research issues in mobile cloud computing. The first part investigates how to analytically formulate the stochastic characteristics of run-time application executions, based on which the workload offloading decisions are probabilistically made and systematic techniques are developed to practically enforce such decisions. The second part incorporates the contexts and performance requirements of mobile cloud applications into the design of wireless networks, so as to adaptively balance between the wireless energy cost and application performance in mobile clouds through fundamental redesign of wireless transmission scheduling algorithms. The third part focuses on testbed development to automatically investigate the run-time system and network dynamics of mobile cloud applications in practice. This testbed consists of off-the-shelf smartphones and wearable devices, and enables in-field experiments for evaluating the performance of the proposed techniques and system designs.

por.por_cntn:
One of the most important challenges in mobile computing is to address the contradiction between the increasing complexity of mobile user applications and the limited lifespan of mobile devices’ battery. A viable solution to this challenge is to integrate mobile devices into the cloud, to which the devices’ local computational workloads are offloaded and executed remotely. The driving vision of this project, hence, is that exploitation of critical dynamics in mobile clouds is indispensable to efficient, prompt, and reliable workload offloading. This project takes two aspects of such dynamics into account: i) system dynamics, referring to the run-time heterogeneity of the execution patterns of mobile applications due to the various environmental contexts, and ii) network dynamics, referring to the varying characteristics of wireless network conditions, configurations, and operations. We developed a set of technologies and engineering systems to exploit these dynamics in mobile clouds to improve the efficiency, promptness and reliability of mobile cloud operations.

First, to investigate and exploit the run-time mobile system dynamics, we developed quantitative models on depicting the dynamic characteristics of run-time application executions, based on program behavior traces collected from real mobile applications. These models formulate such executions using an order-k semi-Markov model, and can depict the heterogeneous characteristics of method invocation dependence and method execution times. Based on this formulation, we further developed probabilistic methods for workload offloading, and also devised systematic techniques that support fine-grained workload migration with minimum computation and communication overhead on commodity mobile OS platforms (e.g., Android).

Second, we also developed new wireless scheduling algorithms to regulate the transmission of mobile program data between mobile devices and the remote cloud, so as to adaptively tradeoff between the wireless energy cost and mobile application performance. These scheduling algorithms take both causality and run-time dynamics of the mobile programs’ method invocations into account, so as to minimize the power consumption of transmitting mobile program data to the cloud, without violating the delay constraints of mobile program execution. Evaluation results have shown that these algorithms can significantly improve the energy efficiency of mobile cloud operations.

We have implemented the above mobile system and network protocol designs over practical mobile system testbeds, and conducted various real experiments to demonstrate their applicability in real-world mobile cloud scenarios. Such experimentation includes code instrumentation over a large collection of Android applications, and demonstrated significant performance improvement over different mobile platforms.

Many of the research results have been integrated with the education curricula at the University of Tennessee Knoxville and the University of Pittsburgh. The project has supported two Ph.D.  students working on their dissertations, and the research outcome has also been used to involve two undergraduate students into research. The involvement of the graduate and undergraduate students will prepare them for leadership roles in computer science research, academia, and industry.
